title: Two Officers in Tamir Rice’s Fatal Shooting Won’t Face Federal Charges
sub_head: Action closes probe into case that helped spark conversation on police use of force against Black Americans
body:
Federal prosecutors said Tuesday they wouldn’t bring federal charges against two police officers in the fatal police shooting of Tamir Rice, a 12-year-old Cleveland boy who was killed in 2014 while playing with a toy gun.
The action closes a long-running civil-rights investigation into a case that helped spark a nationwide conversation on police use of force against Black Americans.
Prosecutors informed Tamir’s family of their decision this week and released a statement to the media on Tuesday, saying the boy’s death at the hands of two officers didn’t meet the standard for bringing federal civil-rights charges against the police.
To bring such charges, prosecutors would need to prove that the officers’ use of force was unreasonable and that the officers broke the law willfully and deliberately. The split-second decision to open fire on Tamir, based on the officers’ stated belief that the toy gun was a real threat, didn’t meet that burden, according to the department.
“Although Tamir Rice’s death is tragic, the evidence does not meet these substantial evidentiary requirements,” the Justice Department said.
